questions.text: Match following parasites with their larval forms:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

These are all examples of cyclophyllidean cestodes.

  • Most cestodes require two hosts to complete their life cycle, with the exception of Hymenolepis nana, in which both the adult worm and larval forms occur within a single host.
  • In general, humans act as the definitive hosts, except in Echinococcus granulosus and Multiceps multiceps, where humans serve as intermediate hosts, developing hydatid cysts and coenuri, respectively.
  • Cestode larvae are produced within intermediate hosts: for example, eggs of Taenia saginatadevelop into cysticercus bovis in cattle, while H. nana produces cysticercoids in humans.

questions.text: In context to scolex (Head), identify the odd one -
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • All above-mentioned cestodes have scolex having rostellum with hooklets, while scolex of T.saginata is quadrate without protrusible rostellum.
  • Examination of the head part is important for species identification.
  • Taenia solium and E.granulosus have a rostelum with a double row of hooklets.

Explanation of other options:

  • Taenia solium (Option A): Has a scolex with 4 suckers and a rostellum with a double crown of hooks.
  • Echinococcus granulosus (Option C):Has a scolex with 4 suckers and a rostellum with a double crown of hooks.
  • Hymenolepis nana (Option D):Has a scolex with 4 suckers and a rostellum with a single crown of hooks.

questions.text: A 62-year-old woman in Finland suffers from macrocytic anemia. Her history is significant for frequent consumption of pickled fish. A stool sample reveals parasitic ova like the one shown in the figure. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • In the above case scenario, the patient with macrocytic anemia, history of frequent consumption of pickled fish along with given image is showing operculated eggs with knob at one end likely diagnosed with Diphyllobothriasis which is caused by diphyllobothrium latum (fish tape worm).
  • This parasite is commonly acquired by eating undercooked or pickled fish, particularly freshwater fish like pike, perch, or salmon.
  • Diphyllobothrium latum can cause macrocytic anemia due to vitamin B12 deficiency, which is a hallmark of diphyllobothriasis.
  • The tapeworm competes with the host for vitamin B12 in the intestines, leading to megaloblastic anemia (macrocytic anemia).

Explanation of other options:

Clonorchis sinensis (Option A): It is a liver fluke that causes clonorchiasis

  • The definitive hosts are usually humans and carnivores (such as dogs and cats), and the intermediate hosts are freshwater snails and fish.
  • This parasite is typically transmitted by ingesting undercooked or pickled freshwater fish containing encysted larvae.
  • The infection often leads to cholangitis, biliary obstruction, and liver fibrosis, but macrocytic anemia is not a prominent feature.

Paragonimus westermani(Option B): is a lung fluke that causes; paragonimiasis, typically involving pulmonary symptoms such as cough,hemoptysis, and chest pain.

  • The infection is contracted by eating undercooked or pickled freshwater crustaceans(such as crabs or crayfish), not fish.
  • This parasite does not typically cause macrocytic anemia and is less likely to be associated with pickled fish consumption.

Opisthorchis species(Option D): Opisthorchis species, including Opisthorchis felineus and Opisthorchis viverrini, are liver flukes that cause opisthorchiasis, a disease of the liver and bile ducts.

  • Opisthorchis infection does not typically cause macrocytic anemia, and it is not as commonly associated with macrocytic anemia as Diphyllobothrium latum.

questions.text: Taenia saginata differs from Taenia solium in all the following aspects except -
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The eggs of Taenia saginata and Taenia soliumare morphologically identical under a light microscope.
  • Both appear as spherical, brownish eggs with a thick, radially striated shell (often called the "embryophore") containing a six-hooked embryo (oncosphere). Therefore, the morphology of the eggs cannot be used to differentiate between the two species.

Explanation of other options:

Scolex(Option A):Taenia saginata has a larger, more rounded scolex with four strong suckers but lacks hooks.Taenia solium has a smaller, globular scolex with four suckers and a rostelum having two rows of hooklets.

Number of Proglottids(Option B):Taenia saginata typically has more proglottids (up to 2000).Taenia solium typically has fewer proglottids (less than 1000).

Number of Lateral Uterine Branches(Option C):Taenia saginata usually has 15-30 uterine branches in each proglottid.Taenia solium has fewer uterine branches, typically < 15 in each proglottid.

questions.text: A 16-year-old girl presents with headache, vomiting, and confusion for 15 days, followed by seizures. MRI shows bilateral cystic brain lesions, and a brain biopsy reveals cystic lesions. After treatment with albendazole and corticosteroids, following which her condition has improved. An adult worm expelled after drugs is shown in figure. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

In the given clinical scenario the presence of cystic brain lesions with an invaginated scolex along with expulsion of an adult worm after albendazole therapy is diagnostic of neurocysticercosis caused by Taenia solium.

The cystic lesions represent cysticercus larvae, while the scolex of T. solium with its four suckers and a rostellum bearing a double crown of hooks as shown in the image is a key feature distinguishing it from Taenia saginata, which lacks hooks.

Neurocysticercosis is a major cause of seizures in endemic regions, and recognition of these morphological and clinical features is essential for diagnosis.

Explanation of other options:

Echinococcus granulosus(Option B): Hydatid disease, caused by Echinococcus granulosus, can also present with cystic lesions in the brain, but hydatid cysts are usually solitary and often contain multiple invaginated protoscolices rather than a single scolex. Additionally, E. granulosus cysts do not expel adult worms.

Taenia saginata(Option C): It is the beef tapeworm and does not cause neurocysticercosis. It primarily leads to intestinal infections but does not produce cysts in the brain. It does not cause the characteristic cystic lesions seen in this patient.

Taenia multiceps(Option D): Taenia multiceps causes coenurosis, which typically affects subcutaneous tissue or muscles, producing nodules rather than cystic lesions in the brain. The lesions are often larger and may contain multiple invaginated scolices, which is not consistent with this case.

choices.text: Caused due to eating of beef
Serological test for antibody detection is not available
Antigen can be detected in serum or CSF by ELISA

questions.text: Regarding neurocysticercosis, which of the following is most accurate?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Antigen detection assays (typically using ELISA) are available and can be used on serum or cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) to diagnose neurocysticercosis.

A patient presenting with new-onset seizures, progressive headaches, and a history of undercooked pork consumption who shows multiple cystic brain lesions on MRI is highly suggestive of neurocysticercosis, caused by the larval stage of Taenia solium (pork tapeworm).

Diagnosis can be supported by detection of circulating antigens in serum or CSF using immunoassays such as ELISA, which identify antigens released from the cysts. These tests are particularly useful when clinical presentation and neuroimaging strongly indicate the disease.

Explanation of incorrect options:

It is caused by eating beef(Option A): Neurocysticercosis is caused by ingestion of Taenia solium eggs, which are typically transmitted through undercooked pork (not beef).

When humans eat pork contaminated with the larvae (cysticerci), the larvae can mature into adult tapeworms in the intestines, and the eggs can be passed in the stool.

These eggs can contaminate food or water sources, leading to autoinfection or the ingestion of the eggs, which then develop into cysts in the brain or other tissues.

Serological tests for antibody detection are not available(Option B): Serological tests to detect antibodies against Taenia solium or its antigens are available and can be used as an important diagnostic tool for neurocysticercosis. These tests can be performed on blood or cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) to help confirm the diagnosis, especially when imaging findings are ambiguous. ELISA (enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay) for antibodies or antigens is a commonly used diagnostic methods.

It is usually treated with metronidazole(Option D): Metronidazole is not the standard treatment for neurocysticercosis. The mainstay of treatment for neurocysticercosis includes:

  • Antiparasitic drugs, such as albendazole or praziquantel, which target the cysticerci (larval stage of Taenia solium).
  • Corticosteroids may also be used to reduce inflammation and control edema around the cysts.
  • Seizures are typically managed with antiepileptic drugs.

questions.text: Worms shown below in picture were recovered from stool specimens of several dogs that work in sheep ranches. Examination reveals tapeworms that measure <10 mm (shown in the image). Which medically important disease is linked to this worm?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Echinococcosis (also known as hydatid disease) is caused by the tapeworm Echinococcus species, particularly Echinococcus granulosus (the most common species responsible for hydatid cysts in humans).

This disease involves dogs as the definitive host, which harbor the adult tapeworm in their intestines.

The life cycle of Echinococcus granulosus involves two hosts: the definitive host (typically dogs or other carnivores) and the intermediate host (usually herbivores like sheep or cattle, or humans as accidental hosts).

In the definitive host, adult tapeworms live in the intestines and release eggs in the feces. These eggs contaminate the environment, and when ingested by an intermediate host, the eggs hatch into larvae that penetrate the intestinal wall and travel to organs (most commonly the liver and lungs).

There, they form cysts containing protoscolices (larval tapeworms). Carnivores become infected by eating the organs of infected intermediate hosts, completing the cycle. Humans can accidentally ingest eggs from contaminated food, water, or soil, leading to the formation of hydatid cysts in their organs.

Explanation of other options:

Schistosomiasis(Option B): It is caused by flukes, not tapeworms, and the worms in question are much larger and not observed in dogs with sheep-related activity.

Diphyllobothriasis(Option C): It is caused by the tapeworm Diphyllobothrium latum and is typically associated with the consumption of raw fish. This tapeworm can grow to lengths of several meters, much longer than the small (10 mm) tapeworms described in this case.

Taeniasis(Option D): It is caused by the tapeworms of the genus Taenia, particularly Taenia solium (pork tapeworm) or Taenia saginata (beef tapeworm). These tapeworms can grow to several meters in length, much larger than the tapeworms described here (less than 10 mm).

  • Taenia species typically infect humans who ingest undercooked pork or beef containing cysticerci (larval tapeworms).
  • While dogs can sometimes harbor Taenia larvae, the tapeworms associated with taeniasis are generally much larger than 10 mm.

choices.text: Good but only if he undergoes long-term therapy for visceral larva migrans
Guarded because of the development of secondary Echinococcosis
He will die in less than a month as a result of spread of cryptosporidiosis
Poor because of likelihood of disseminated amoebiasis

questions.text: A 67-year-old man undergoes a cholecystectomy, and during the procedure a liver cyst is discovered (shown in the image). During surgical removal of cyst, an error allows for a significant amount of cyst fluid (contents shown) to spill out into the abdominal cavity. Epinephrine averts an anaphylactic attack, and his immediate recovery proves uneventful. But, what is his long-term prognosis as a result of the surgical mishap?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • This is a case of Hydatid cyst caused by E.granulosus.
  • Hydatid fluid present in cyst is antigenic.
  • When cyst ruptures, it can lead to severe anaphylactic reactions due to prior sensitization of antigen, due to seepage of minute amounts of fluid through the capsule.
  • Because of the presence of brood capsules containing protoscolices, secondary Echinococcosis develops leading to dissemination of hydatid cyst and it is a difficult situation to treat.

Explanation of other options:

Good but only if he undergoes long-term therapy for visceral larva migrans(Option A): Visceral larva migrans (VLM) is caused by the migration of larvae of roundworms like Toxocara canis (from dogs) or Toxocara cati (from cats). VLM typically causes systemic symptoms due to the migration of larvae through the liver, lungs, and other organs.

  • VLM is not related to cystic lesions like the one described in this patient. The cyst in the liver is far more suggestive of echinococcosis, and not visceral larva migrans. While VLM can cause visceral symptoms, it would not cause a liver cyst nor would the cyst fluid spilling into the abdomen trigger VLM.

He will die in less than a month as a result of spread of cryptosporidiosis(Option C): Cryptosporidiosis is caused by the protozoan parasite Cryptosporidium, which typically infects the gastrointestinal tract and causes diarrhea. It is often a concern in immunocompromised patients, especially those with HIV/AIDS. Cryptosporidiosis typically does not cause liver cysts.

Poor because of likelihood of disseminated amoebiasis(Option D): Amoebiasis is caused by Entamoeba histolytica and typically results in intestinal and extra-intestinal infections, particularly involving the liver (liver abscess). Amoebiasis can be serious, especially in the setting of dissemination (spread to other organs), but it usually presents with bloody diarrhea, liver abscess, or extra-intestinal disease, and not with the formation of liver cysts as described here.

questions.text: A nurse reports that several children in an emergency shelter are suffering from gastrointestinal symptoms. Fecal samples from symptomatic and asymptomatic children test positive for ova and worm fragments approximately 1 cm in length as shown in the images. What is the most likely identification of the parasite?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The characteristic non-bile-stained eggs with hexacanth embryo are suggestive of H.nana.
  • It has a thin colorless outer membrane and inner embryophore enclosing the hexacanth oncosphere.
  • The space between two membranes contains yolk granules and 4-8 thread like polar filaments arising from two knobs on the embryophore.
  • The eggs float in a saturated solution of salt and are non bile stained.
  • They are immediately infectious and unable to survive for more than 10 days in an external environment.
  • Scolex having four suckers and retractile rostellum with a single row of hooklets confirms diagnosis. H.nana commonly infects children, and most infections are asymptomatic. Many times, demonstrations of eggs are incidental findings when looking for other pathogens.

Bile not stained(egg)

  • N-Necator Americana
  • E-Enterobius vermicularis
  • H-H. Nana
  • A-Ancylostoma duodenale

(Mnemonic-NEHA)

Explanation of other options:

E.vermicularis(Option B): Non bile stained, plano-convex shape.

A.duodenale(Option C): Non bile stained egg and segmented ovum with 4-8 blastomeres.


A.lumbricoides(Option A):

questions.text: Match the following:
questions.solution: Explanation:

questions.text: A 45-year-old male from a rural area in sub-Saharan Africa presents with diarrhea, fatigue, and blood in the stool. He has a history of swimming in freshwater lakes. Stool examination reveals the presence of eggs with a characteristic lateral spine. Which parasite is most likely responsible for this patient's condition and treatment for this patient?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • In the given clinical scenario the patient's presentation and diagnostic findings point definitively to Schistosoma mansoni infection (intestinal schistosomiasis).
  • This infection is endemic in Sub-Saharan Africa, where exposure typically occurs during swimming or wading in freshwater lakes contaminated with cercariae released by infected snails.
  • The larvae penetrate the skin and migrate to the mesenteric veins of the colon, where adult worms reside and produce eggs.
  • Clinical features include chronic diarrhea and dysentery with blood in stool, resulting from egg-induced inflammation, ulceration, and bleeding of the intestinal wall. Diagnosis is confirmed by the presence of stool eggs with a characteristic lateral spine, which is pathognomonic.
  • Praziquantelis the treatment of choice for all schistosome species and forms the cornerstone of both individual therapy and mass drug administration programs in endemic regions.

Explanation of other options:

  • Schistosoma japonicum, Praziquantel (Option A):While Praziquantel is the correct treatment, S. japonicum is found in Asia (China, Philippines, Indonesia), not sub-Saharan Africa. Its eggs are smaller and rounder with a small, lateral knob that is difficult to see.
  • Schistosoma haematobium, Albendazole (option B): haematobium causes urinary schistosomiasis(hematuria, bladder pathology), not intestinal symptoms with bloody diarrhea. Its eggs have a terminal spine, not a lateral one and Albendazole is not the treatment for schistosomiasis, it is used for nematode infections like pinworm, hookworm, and ascariasis.
  • Entamoeba histolytica, Metronidazole (Option D):Entamoeba histolytica can cause dysentery (bloody diarrhea) and Metronidazole is the correct treatment for it, it is a protozoan and does not produce eggs. The key finding of lateral-spined eggs in the stool rules out an amoebic cause and confirms a Schistosoma infection.

questions.text: A patient presents with dermatitis after swimming in freshwater contaminated with snail populations. Microscopic examination of the skin biopsy reveals larval stages of Schistosoma. Which larval form is most likely responsible for initiating the infection?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Cercariae are infective forms to humans, which enter through skin penetration.

  • Once inside the blood vessels, they lose their tails and convert into schistosomules.
  • When they reach mesenteric venous plexuses, they convert into adult forms.
  • Living in copula, females produce eggs, which pass along with feces or urine, and reach water.
  • Eggs containing ciliated embryos (miracidium) hatch immediately and release miracidium.
  • Miracidium enters snails and successively passes through stages of first and second generation sporocyst.(Option A ruled out)
  • Sporocyst converts into cercariae which escape from snails in water.
  • The stage of redia is not found in Schistosomes. (Option B ruled out)

Explanation of other options:

  • Miracidium (Option A): This is the ciliated, free-swimming larval stage that hatches from the egg in water. Its function is to find and infect a specific species of snail (the intermediate host). It does not infect humans and cannot penetrate human skin.
  • Sporocyst (Option C): This is another larval stage that develops inside the snail. The miracidium penetrates the snail and transforms into a primary (mother) sporocyst. The sporocyst is essentially a sac that gives rise to the next generation (either rediae or, in some species, directly to cercariae). It is entirely confined to the snail's tissues.

questions.text: A 32-year-old man from a rural agricultural area presents to the clinic with a 3-week history of right upper quadrant abdominal pain, fever, and intermittent jaundice. He reports consuming undercooked liver from sheep several times in the past few months. Laboratory findings show elevated liver enzymes, eosinophilia, and mild anemia. Which of the following is the most likely cause of his symptoms?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

In the above clinical vignette, based on clinical symptoms and laboratory findings such as eosinophilia,it suggests parasitic infection .The parasite acquired through consuming undercooked liver from sheep.

  • Fasciola hepatica is a liver fluke that is primarily transmitted through the consumption of contaminated, undercooked freshwater plants or the liver of infected animals (e.g., sheep, cattle).
  • The patient in the scenario has a history of consuming undercooked sheep liver, which is a typical route of transmission for Fasciola hepatica.
  • Clinical presentation:
    • Symptoms such as right upper quadrant abdominal pain, fever, jaundice, and eosinophilia are common in Fasciola hepatica infection.
  • The liver fluke can cause fascioliasis, which often affects the liver and biliary system, leading to biliary colic, cholangitis, and even obstructive jaundice.
  • The ultrasound findings of biliary duct dilation and thickening of the gallbladder wall are characteristic of Fasciola infection.

Explanation of other options:

Schistosoma mansoni(Option B): It is a trematode that causes schistosomiasis. It is typically contracted through skin contact with contaminated freshwater, where the larvae (cercariae) penetrate the skin. The primary organ affected by Schistosoma mansoni is the liver (leading to portal hypertension, splenomegaly, and sometimes cirrhosis), but it does not typically cause symptoms like biliary duct dilation or a thickened gallbladder wall seen in Fasciola hepatica.

Entamoeba histolytica(Option C): It is a protozoan parasite that causes amoebiasis, primarily affecting the colon but can occasionally spread to the liver, causing an amoebic liver abscess. However, it typically presents with more gastrointestinal symptoms such as diarrhea, dysentery, and abdominal pain.

Giardia lamblia(Option D): It is a protozoan parasite that causes giardiasis, primarily affecting the small intestine. It is transmitted via contaminated water and causes symptoms like diarrhea, bloating, abdominal cramping, and sometimes nausea, but does not typically cause liver or biliary tract symptoms

questions.text: Chronic infection with Fasciola hepatica can lead to all except?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Fasciola hepatica infection, unlike Clonorchis sinensis and Opisthorchis viverrini, is not associated with cholangiocarcinoma.
  • Humans, sheep, or cattle acquire the infection by ingesting metacercariae encysted on aquatic vegetation. After excysting in the duodenum, the larvae penetrate the intestinal wall, migrate through the peritoneal cavity and Glisson's capsule, traverse the liver parenchyma, and finally mature into adult worms within the biliary passages.
  • Compared with clonorchiasis, fascioliasis produces greater mechanical damage due to the larger size of F. hepatica.
  • Clinically, the acute phase presents with fever, right upper quadrant pain, tender hepatomegaly, and eosinophilia, while the chronic phase is characterized by biliary obstruction, cirrhosis, obstructive jaundice, cholelithiasis, and anemia.

Explanation of other options:

  • Cholangitis (Option A): The adult flukes residing in the bile ducts cause mechanical obstruction, inflammation, and epithelial damage, predisposing to bacterial superinfection and recurrent episodes of cholangitis.
  • Portal hypertension (Option C): The chronic inflammatory reaction and periductal fibrosis in the liver, especially in heavy and long-standing infections, can lead to hepatic fibrosis. This can distort the architecture and contribute to increased resistance to blood flow, resulting in portal hypertension.
  • Biliary cirrhosis (Option D): Long-standing fasciola infection and the associated mechanical and inflammatory damage to the bile ducts can lead to chronic biliary obstruction, periportal fibrosis, and eventually secondary biliary cirrhosis.

questions.text: Match the following
questions.solution: Explanation:

questions.text: A Korean visitor who came to India is admitted to hospital because of chest pain and night sweats. He has had a productive cough since arriving in India, now he has a few episodes of hemoptysis too. The sputum sample is speckled with brown granules, which upon microscopic examination are identified as parasite ova. These same ova are present in the stool (shown in the image). What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The given image is showing an operculated egg ,probably a trematode infection. The clinical features suggestive of lung infection, probably caused by paragonimus westermani.
  • P. westermani is a lung fluke which causes peribronchial granuloma and pneumonitis. The combination of chest pain, productive cough, and hemoptysis (coughing up blood)is the hallmark of pulmonary paragonimiasis, often mimicking tuberculosis.
  • Viscous septum is speckled with golden brown eggs. Presence of operculated, golden-brown, 100 x 50 μ size eggs are diagnostics.
  • Infection occurs due to consumption of raw or undercooked crab or crayfish which is practiced in parts of Southeast Asia like Korea, Taiwan, China & Japan.

Parasites with Operculated eggs:

Explanation of other options:

  • C. sinensis (Clonorchis sinensis) (Option A):This is the Chinese liver fluke. It causes biliary tract disease (cholangitis, cholangiocarcinoma), not pulmonary symptoms. Its eggs are found only in stool, not in sputum, and are smaller with a prominent shoulder and operculum.
  • F. hepatica (Fasciola hepatica) (Option C):This is the sheep liver fluke. It causes hepatic disease (hepatitis, biliary obstruction) during its migration through the liver. It does not cause pulmonary symptoms or hemoptysis. Its eggs are very large and operculated, found only in stool, not in sputum.
  • F. buski (Fasciolopsis buski) (Option D):This is the giant intestinal fluke. It resides in the small intestine and causes intestinal symptoms like diarrhea and malabsorption. It does not involve the lungs, and its eggs are found only in stool.

questions.text: A resident of India who was employed as a river guide for a safari and adventure enterprise in a central African nation returns to the country for treatment of hepatic disease and dysentery. Surgical biopsy of the colon reveals granulomas (shown in the first image). Parasite ova are also noted in the stool examination (shown in the second image). What is the most likely parasite agent responsible for this condition?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

In the given clinical scenario, the patient worked as a river guide in Central Africa. This is a classic endemic region for S. mansoni.

S. japonicum is found in Asia, and S. haematobium is also in Africa but causes different symptoms.

The patient has hepatic disease and dysentery.

  • Hepatic Disease: S. mansoni eggs embolize to the liver, leading to periportal fibrosis ("pipestem fibrosis") and portal hypertension.
  • Dysentery: The adult worms reside in the inferior mesenteric veins draining the large intestine (colon and rectum). Eggs laid in these vessels penetrate the intestinal wall, causing granulomatous inflammation, ulceration, and bloody diarrhea (dysentery).

The colonic biopsy showing granulomas is a classic histological finding in schistosomiasis, caused by the host's immune response to the eggs.

The description of the egg in the stool is crucial. S. mansoni eggs are characterized by a large, lateral spine. This distinguishes them from the terminal-spined egg of S. haematobium and the small, lateral knob of S. japonicum.

Thus the symptoms and lab findings suggest s.mansoni infection.

Explanation of other options:

Schistosoma haematobium(Option A): It is a species of schistosoma that primarily causes urogenital schistosomiasis, affecting the bladder and urinary tract. It is typically associated with hematuria (blood in urine) and bladder fibrosis or cancer in chronic cases.Schistosoma haematobium eggs has terminal pointed spine.

Schistosoma japonicum(Option B): It is another species that causes intestinal and hepatic schistosomiasisHowever, this species tends to produce more rounded eggs with a small, slightly off-center rounded knob, which may not be easily identifiable in a stool sample compared to mansoni's lateral-spined eggs.

Schistosoma intercalatum(Option C): It is a lesser-known species of schistosoma.It is similar to mansoni in causing intestinal and hepatic schistosomiasis but is generally rarer and causes milder disease.

  • Intercalatum eggs are often smaller than those of S. mansoni and are difficult to distinguish. While it can cause granulomas and liver involvement, it is much less common than S. mansoni, and the overall clinical presentation would typically be less severe.

questions.text: Tourists visiting a primitive tropical island are assured that the untreated water supply is safe for bathing because it originates from a pristine river. However, water analysis reveals infestation with the organism shown in the image. Based on the photo, what are tourists who bathe in unheated water from this river at risk for?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The given image is cercarial larva of schistosoma, the cercaria has an elongated ovoid body and forked tail(furcocercous cercaria), while cercariae of other trematodes are not bifurcated.

  • Bathing in untreated, freshwater river water from a tropical region this strongly suggests a waterborne helminthic infection, particularly Schistosoma, whose infective cercariae penetrate intact skin.

  • The life cycle of Schistosoma begins when male and female adult worms, residing in the hepato-portal circulation, mate.
  • The paired worms ascend the mesenteric veins against the flow of blood.
  • S. japonicum migrates to the superior mesenteric vein, reaching the venous radicals of the small intestine and ascending colon.
  • S. mansoni and S. haematobium follow the inferior mesenteric route.
    • S. mansoni settles in the veins of the descending colon and rectum,
    • while S. haematobium travels through the hemorrhoidal plexus to reach the venous plexus of the bladder and pelvic organs.
  • These adults use their suckers for attachment, and the male worm carries the female in his ventral groove (“schist”) throughout their lifespan.
  • The cycle continues as eggs are laid and excreted into the environment to infect snails, the intermediate host completing the cycle.

Explanation of other options:

Naegleria fowleri(Option A): is a free-living amoeba that can cause a rare but severe brain infection known as primary amoebic meningoencephalitis (PAM). The amoeba is commonly found in warm freshwater environments, such as hot springs, lakes, and poorly maintained swimming pools.Morphological forms are: Cyst,amoeboid and flagellate trophozoite. Naegleria fowleri (amoeboid trophozoite and flagellate trophozoite) enters the body through the nasal passages (not through the skin) when people swim or dive into contaminated warm water.

Fasciolopsis(Option C): This refers to Fasciolopsis buski, a parasitic flatworm that causes fascioliasis, usually contracted by ingesting contaminated water plants.In this free living cercaria is not bifurcated and it is not an infective form. Cercaria encyst to form metacercaria on water plants. These water plants ingested by humans, they got the infection.

D.medinensis(Option D):This refers to Dracunculus medinensis, the causative agent of Guinea worm disease. Ingestion of contaminated water containing larvae is the primary transmission route, not direct skin contact.

questions.text: The only fluke inhabiting large intestine is
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Gastrodiscoides hominis is a trematode (fluke) that is unique among the common human-infecting flukes because its adult form resides in the cecum and colon (large intestine) of humans and pigs. It attaches to the mucosal wall, causing inflammation and diarrhea.

Flukes inhabiting the intestine are :

  • Fasiolopsis buski
  • heterophytes,
  • Metagonimus yokogawai,
  • Watsonius watsoni,
  • Echinostoma and Gastrodiscoides hominis.
  • All inhabit the small intestine except G.hominis which inhabit the large intestine.

Explanation of other options:

Fasciolopsis buski(Option A): It is a trematode (fluke) that primarily inhabits the small intestine, not the large intestine.

Clonorchis sinensis(Option C), also known as the Chinese liver fluke, is a trematode that primarily inhabits the liver and bile ducts of humans and other mammals.

Paragonimus westermani(Option D): Paragonimus westermani resides in the lungs of its host, where it causes inflammatory responses and symptoms like chronic cough, hemoptysis (coughing up blood), and chest pain. It can also affect other organs like the brain or intestines in some cases, but it is primarily a pulmonary parasite.

choices.text: Develop at the site of cercarial penetration
Severe when infection with cercariae of nonhuman schistosomes
Produced mild infection in previously exposed persons
Type-1 hypersensitivity reaction to cercarial antigen

questions.text: Which of the following is incorrect about swimmer's itch?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

In sensitized people who have previously been infected, the rash can develop into itchy, red, raised lesions. Previous infections with cercariae cause a faster onset and worse presentation of dermatitis due to the stronger immune response. "Swimmer's itch" (cercarial dermatitis) is a self-limiting condition, not an established infection.

Swimmer's itch: It is part of acute schistosomiasis, which is caused by schistosome species

During skin penetration of cercariae,intense irritation and skin rash may develop at the site of cercarial penetration. (Option A ruled out)

Swimmer's itch is caused by a Type I hypersensitivity reaction (IgE-mediated) to the antigens released by the cercariae during their penetration of the skin. (Option D ruled out)

This reaction involves the release of histamine and other mediators from mast cells, leading to itching, redness, and inflammation.

When humans are exposed to cercariae from nonhuman species, the infection is usually more severe because humans are not the natural host for these schistosomes. The immune response is exaggerated, leading to the characteristic symptoms. (option B ruled out)

questions.text: Match following trematode with their mode of infection -
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Cercariae or metacercariae are infective forms for trematode infections.
  • There are various ways by which they enter our body.
  • Cercariae of Schistosomes, in water directly penetrates skin, while in other trematodes, these cercariae encyst in various aquatic hosts like vegetation (F.hepatica), fish (C.sinensis) and Crab (P.westermani) and ingestion of these metacercariae leads to infections.

choices.text: Inflammatory response to eggs in the gut
Migration of larvae through the lungs
Invasion of larvae into the liver
A secondary bacterial infection in the intestines

questions.text: Which of the following is the most likely cause of the "Löffler's syndrome" in Ascaris lumbricoides infection?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Löffler's syndrome is a clinical condition characterized by eosinophilia, pulmonary infiltrates, and fever, which is typically associated with the larval migration of Ascaris lumbricoides through the lungs.

Ascaris larvae hatch in the intestines, travel through the bloodstream to the lungs, and then migrate up the bronchial tree, causing an inflammatory response in the lungs, which leads to Löffler's syndrome.

Explanation of other options:

Inflammatory response to eggs in the gut (Option A): This does not directly cause Löffler's syndrome. The eggs are laid in the intestines but do not directly induce the pulmonary symptoms.

Invasion of larvae into the liver (Option C): Ascaris larvae do not typically invade the liver; their migration is primarily through the lungs.

A secondary bacterial infection in the intestines (Option D): While secondary infections can occur, they are not the primary cause of Löffler's syndrome, which is specifically due to the larval migration through the lungs.

choices.text: Presence of a clear, colorless shell
A smooth, transparent membrane with no visible surface texture
A thick, mamillated (rough) shell with a hyaline or clear appearance
Presence of two symmetrical openings at each end

questions.text: In a stool sample from a patient presenting with gastrointestinal symptoms, which of the following microscopic features of Ascaris lumbricoides eggs would most likely help distinguish them from other parasitic eggs?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • In stool microscopy, Ascaris lumbricoides eggs are distinguished by their thick, mamillated rough shell(Option B ruled out)and hyaline (clear) appearance.
  • This feature helps differentiate them from other parasitic eggs, which may have smoother or differently textured shells.
  • The rough surface of the egg is unique to Ascaris and is often stained brown by bile pigments. (Option A ruled out)

Explanation of other options:

  • Presence of two symmetrical openings at each end (Option D):This is the classic description of the eggs of Trichuris trichiura (whipworm). These eggs are barrel-shaped with prominent bipolar plugs, which is a feature entirely different from the Ascaris egg's mamillated coat.

choices.text: The eggs are ingested, hatch in the small intestine, and the larvae mature into adult worms in the colon
The adult female worms lay eggs around the perianal area, and the larvae inside the eggs hatch in the environment
The eggs are ingested, hatch in the stomach, and larvae migrate through the bloodstream to the lungs before returning to the intestines
Adult worms lay eggs in the colon, and the larvae hatch directly in the intestines without passing through the lungs

questions.text: A 5-year-old child presents to the clinic with complaints of perianal itching, particularly at night. A stool sample is collected, and upon examination, a parasitic egg is identified as shown in the image. Which of the following best describes the life cycle of causative agents?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The given image is showing planoconvex shaped, non bile stained parasitic egg suggestive of enterobius vermicularis infection, it strongly correlates with patient's symptoms.

  • The life cycle of Enterobius vermicularis involves the ingestion of eggs, which hatch in the small intestine.
  • The larvae then mature into adult worms in the colon.
  • The female worms migrate to the perianal area to lay eggs, causing the characteristic itching.
  • The eggs are then deposited around the anus, where they can be transferred to other surfaces, contributing to transmission when the child scratches and touches objects or other people.
  • This life cycle explains the common symptom of perianal itching, which is typically worse at night when the female worms lay their eggs.
  • The condition is highly contagious, often transmitted through the fecal-oral route.

Explanation of other options:

  • The adult female worms lay eggs around the perianal area, and the larvae inside the eggs hatch in the environment (Option B): The eggs are laid on perianal skin but the larvae do nothatch in the environment. The eggs must be ingested by a host to hatch. The infective stage is the egg, not a free larva.
  • The eggs are ingested, hatch in the stomach, and larvae migrate through the bloodstream to the lungs before returning to the intestines (Option C): This describes the complex tissue-migratory life cycleof other nematodes like Ascaris lumbricoides (the roundworm). Enterobius has no lung migration stage.
  • Adult worms lay eggs in the colon, and the larvae hatch directly in the intestines without passing through the lungs (Option D): The eggs are laid on the perianal skinand must be ingested to continue the cycle. If they hatched on the perianal skin, the larvae could potentially re-enter the large intestine (called retroinfection), but this is a minor route.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man from an endemic area presents with swelling of the legs (elephantiasis), fever, and painful lymph nodes. A blood smear taken at night shows microfilariae with characteristic sheath and no nuclei in the tail tip. Which of the following is the most likely causative organism?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

In the given clinical scenario the presentation and diagnostic findings are classic for lymphatic filariasis caused by Wuchereria bancrofti.

  • Clinical Presentation of Swelling of the legs (elephantiasis), fever, and painful lymph nodes (lymphangitis/lymphadenitis) are the hallmark symptoms of chronic lymphatic obstruction and inflammation caused by the adult worms residing in the lymphatic vessels.
  • Nocturnal Periodicity: bancrofti microfilariae exhibit nocturnal periodicity, meaning they are present in the peripheral blood primarily at night to coincide with the biting habits of their mosquito vector (e.g., Culex species).
  • Morphology of Microfilariae:The description of a sheathed microfilaria with no nuclei in the tail tip is pathognomonic for Wuchereria bancrofti. This specific morphology is used to differentiate it from other filarial worms.
  • Wuchereria bancrofti is the most common cause of lymphatic filariasis.

Explanation of other options:

Brugia malayi (Option B): Similar to Wuchereria bancrofti, B. malayi causes filariasis, but it is generally seen in Southeast Asia. The microfilariae of Brugia malayi are also sheathed but have a characteristic nuclei pattern that differs from W. bancrofti.

Loa loa (Option C): Loa loa is responsible for loiasis, which causes eye worm disease. Microfilariae of Loa loa have a sheath but are typically seen in the subcutaneous tissue and blood during the day.

Onchocerca volvulus (Option D): This causes onchocerciasis or river blindness. Microfilariae of Onchocerca volvulus do not have a sheath and are found in skin and subcutaneous tissue, not in the bloodstream.

choices.text: Trichuris trichiura is transmitted by direct contact with infected individuals
The adult worms primarily reside in the small intestine of infected individuals
The diagnosis of Trichuris trichiura infection is commonly confirmed by identifying characteristic eggs in stool samples
Trichuris trichiura is known to cause only asymptomatic infections in all individuals

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true regarding Trichuris trichiura (whipworm) infection in humans?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Demonstration of characteristic eggs in stool is the definitive standard for diagnosing a Trichuris trichiura infection.The adult female worm lays thousands of eggs per day, which are passed in the feces.
  • These eggs have a very distinctive appearance: they are barrel-shaped (elongated oval) with bipolar, mucoid plugs that protrude at each end, giving them a "lemon" or "football" shape. Their identification during a routine ova and parasite (O&P) stool examination is straightforward and confirmatory.

Explanation of other options:

Trichuris trichiura is transmitted by direct contact with infected individuals(Option A):It is transmitted via the fecal-oral route, where human feces containing the eggs contaminate food or water.

The adult worms primarily reside in the small intestine of infected individuals (Option B): The adult worms reside in the large intestine, specifically the cecum and ascending colon. The thin anterior end of the worm threads itself into the superficial mucosa of the colonic wall, which is why it's called the "whipworm."

Trichuris trichiura is known to cause only asymptomatic infections in all individuals (Option D): While light infections are often asymptomatic, heavy worm burdens can cause significant illness. Symptoms can include:

  • Abdominal pain and chronic diarrhea.
  • Trichuris dysentery syndrome:a severe form with bloody diarrhea, anemia, and growth retardation in children.
  • Rectal prolapse (in massive infections, especially in malnourished children).

questions.text: Which of the following parasites is known to cause intestinal re-infection through an auto-infective cycle, leading to hyperinfection syndrome, particularly in immunocompromised individuals?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The condition referred to as intestinal re-infectionor hyperinfection syndrome is specifically associated with Strongyloides stercoralis. This involves the massive dissemination of larvae throughout the body, carrying intestinal bacteria and causing severe complications like Gram-negative sepsis and meningitis.
  • This occurs in individuals with compromised immune systems, such as those with AIDS, lepromatous leprosy, corticosteroid therapy, or severe malnutrition.
  • In these cases, the rhabditiform larvae in the intestines, instead of being excreted in the feces, mature into filariform larvae.
  • These filariform larvae can then penetrate the intestinal mucosa and spread to various tissues and organs, including the lungs, resulting in the hyperinfection syndrome.

Explanation of Other Options:

Trichuris trichiura(Option A): This parasite typically does not cause intestinal re-infection. Its life cycle involves the eggs being passed in feces, and they mature in the environment before being ingested by the host.

Enterobius vermicularis(Option C ): While vermicularis does involve a form of autoinfection (where larvae hatch and migrate retrogradely through the anus or re-infect the host through perianal itching), it is not associated with hyperinfection syndrome. The term "auto-infection" here refers to the re-infection of the host by larvae, rather than the widespread tissue infection seen in S.stercoralis hyperinfection.

Ancylostoma duodenale (Option D): Hookworms have a direct life cycle that requires the development of larvae in the soil. They cannot auto-infect the host internally. The larvae mature in the soil and infect by penetrating the skin; they do not transform into infective stages within the human intestine.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman presents with periorbital swelling, myalgia, and mild gastrointestinal complaints. She reports eating undercooked wild game meat a few days prior. Laboratory investigations reveal peripheral eosinophilia. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Trichinella spiralis is a parasitic nematode that causes trichinosis, a disease resulting from the ingestion of undercooked meat (typically pork or wild game such as bear, which is common in certain regions).

The symptoms include periorbital edema (swelling around the eyes), muscle pain, and sometimes gastrointestinal symptoms such as nausea, vomiting, or diarrhea.

The characteristic muscle pain and swelling occur due to the larvae invading muscle tissue, which can also cause inflammation.

This is the most likely diagnosis in this case because the patient has recently consumed undercooked wild game, which is a known risk factor for Trichinella infection.

Explanation of other options:

Acute viral gastroenteritis(Option A): It usually causes vomiting and diarrhea but not muscle pain or periorbital edema.

Cysticercosis(Option C): This is caused by Taenia solium (pork tapeworm) larvae. While it can cause myalgia (if muscles are involved) and eosinophilia may be present, the classic presentation is seizures or other neurological symptoms from cysts in the brain (neurocysticercosis).

Systemic lupus erythematosus (Option D): SLE is an autoimmune disorder that can cause periorbital edema (e.g., in nephrotic syndrome) and myalgia/arthralgia but it's not triggered by eating undercooked meat and doesn't typically cause muscle pain like trichinosis does.
